para.p:
A model for carbon monoxide poisoning is the following. Consider a gas which is mixture of diatomic oxygen
O 2
and carbon monoxide
⁢ C O
. The sites on the hemoglobin molecule can either be unoccupied, with energy
= E 0
, occupied by an
O 2
molecule with energy
= E
-
⁢ 0.65 eV
, or occupied by a carbon monoxide molecule with energy
= E
-
⁢ 0.85 eV
, see figure.

figure.toccaption: 1Artists conception of problem Carbon Monoxide Poisoning. The large Black circles denote Carbon atoms, while the smaller circles denote Oxygen atoms.
figure.caption: Figure 1Artists conception of problem Carbon Monoxide Poisoning. The large Black circles denote Carbon atoms, while the smaller circles denote Oxygen atoms.

para.p:
In this problem you will calculate the probability that the hemoglobin site will be occupied by an
O 2
(what we want!). This depends on the concentration of
O 2
and sensitively on the concentration of carbon monoxide.

The questions below refer to the surrounding
O 2
gas at a temperature of
⁢ 295 K
and a pressure of
⁢ 0.2 bar
. From the temperature and pressure of
O 2
, the corresponding concentration
= n
/ N V
of the gas can be found, as can its quantum concentration 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1
λ th
is the thermal de Broglie wavelength.

≡
n Q

v Q

n
becomes comparable to the quantum concentration,
∼

⁢ C O
can be found similarly. These values and the atomic numbers of the two atoms are given in the table below.

Without looking up numbers estimate the quantum concentration of
O 2
gas, confirming the result in the table.

Qualitatively explain what determines the ratio of quantum concentrations for the two gasses,
O 2
and
⁢ C O
.

and

I

and

Δ
O 2

O 2

Δ

Recall that the rotational energy levels are

Math.text: formulae@(epsilon _ rot = list@(ell * (ell + 1) * Delta, [with]), ell = list@(0, 1, 2, ldots * infinity))

Determine the chemical potential of the classical diatomic gas as a function of the concentration
n

μ
O 2

O 2

Numerically evaluate the chemical potential

⁢ C O

⁢ C O

⁢ C O

Now return to the hemoglobin sites. By considering the grand partition function of the site, determine the probability that the site is occupied by
O 2

⁢ C O
is a thousand times smaller than
O 2

0.17

Determine how the probability of (e) would change if the density of
⁢ C O
was negligibly small. Ans:
0.976

subsection.title: Problem 2. Gibbs Free Energy for Several Components

para.p:
Consider a gas consisting of three types of particles,
A
,
B
,
C
. A chemical reaction amongst particles converts an atom of
A
plus an atom of
B
to a molecule of
C

The energy is a function of
S
,
V
,
N A
,
N B
and
N C
, i.e.
⁢ U
( S , V ,
N A
,
N B
,
N C
)
. The change in energy is

Math.text: d * U = (T * d * S - p * d * V) + mu _ A * d * N _ A + mu _ B * d * N _ B + mu _ C * d * N _ C

para.p:
This problem will lead you to conclude that equilibirum between
A
,
B
and
C
is reached when

Math.text: mu _ C = mu _ A + mu _ B

para.p:
Define the Gibbs Free energy
= G
+
- U
⁢ T S
⁢ P V

⁢ d G
.
Generalize the scaling argumenents given in the book which led to to Eq. 22.5, to show that

Math.text: G = mu _ A * N _ A + mu _ B * N _ B + mu _ C * N _ C

para.p:
In particular consider how the energy of the system
U

S ,
N A

λ

=

0

A
one atom of
B
and make a
C

Math.text: mu _ C - mu _ A - mu _ B = 0

Equation shows that the degree of ionization goes up when the density

⁢ 10000
K ∘

Math.text: e ^ (- (R / k _ B) * T) = e ^ (- ((13.6 * eV) / k _ B) * 10 ^ 4 * ^ compose K) similar-to-or-equals e ^ [-16.] similar-to 10 ^ (- 7)

para.p: Qualitatively explain why the ionized fraction at this temperature is of order unity in spite of this penalizing factor.
